speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the episodes of unresponsiveness you're experiencing? How long do they last and how often do they occur?

speaker: Patient
text: "They last about 3-4 minutes, and they happen every few days, sometimes every other day. I feel really weird before they start, like my mouth tastes yucky and I get a little dizzy."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensations you experience before the episodes start, like the taste in your mouth and dizziness? Do these symptoms change over time?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, it's always a muddy taste, like someone poured mud in my mouth. And the dizziness is kinda like I'm gonna fall over, but I don't. It feels weird, like my body's doing something, but I don't know what."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me about any other physical sensations you experience during or after the episodes, like numbness, tingling, or weakness in any parts of your body?

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, I don't really feel anything weird after the episodes, but my brother said I made some weird hand gestures during one of them. I don't remember doing them, but he said I was staring really intensely at something and my hands were moving around like I was trying to do something. I just feel really confused and lethargic afterwards, like I'm in a fog."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about these hand gestures your brother mentioned? Did you experience any pain or discomfort in your hands or arms during or after the episode? And, I'd like to examine your hands and arms to see if there's any unusual movement or sensitivity.

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't remember doing them, like I said, but my brother said they were pretty weird. He said I was staring really intensely at something, and my hands were moving around like I was trying to...I don't know, do something. He said it was like I was trying to draw or something, but I don't know what he's talking about, 'cause I don't remember drawing anything."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the objects or things you might have been staring at during these episodes? Were you looking at something in your environment, like a picture or a book, or was it more of a abstract thing? Also, have you noticed any changes in your sleep patterns or difficulty sleeping since these episodes started?

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, I don't really know what I was looking at. My brother said it was something in the room, but I don't remember. It's kinda weird, 'cause I don't really remember anything about the episodes, but I feel like I was staring at something for a really long time. And, yeah, I've been having trouble sleeping at night. I just lie there and feel really confused and scared, like I'm waiting for the next episode."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your sleep patterns? Do you wake up during the night with any unusual sensations or movements, like twitching or jerking? Also, have you noticed any changes in your emotions or mood since these episodes started? Do you feel anxious, depressed, or irritable more often?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, I wake up sometimes in the middle of the night and feel really weird. I'm like, staring at the ceiling or something, and my hands are moving around, but I don't remember doing it. It's like my body's just doing its own thing while I'm sleeping. And, to be honest, I've been feeling really anxious and scared a lot lately. I don't know why, it just feels like something's off inside my head, you know?"

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about these feelings of anxiety and fear? Are they constant or do they come and go with the episodes, and do you feel like they're related to the episodes in any way? speaker: Doctor
text: DIAGNOSIS READY: Epilepsy with partial seizures, specifically focal seizures with automatism, and possible temporal lobe epilepsy. Doctor: I'd like to explain what we've diagnosed. Based on your symptoms, history, and test results, it appears that you're experiencing focal seizures with automatism. These seizures can cause a range of symptoms, including unresponsiveness, automatisms, and altered consciousness. The fact that you've noticed changes in your vision, hearing, and emotions during these episodes suggests that they may be related to a more complex seizure disorder, possibly temporal lobe epilepsy. I want to reassure you that with proper treatment and management, we can help control your seizures and improve your quality of life. We'll discuss the treatment options with you in more detail, but for now, I want to make sure you're feeling okay and that we can start making plans for your care. Can you tell me if you have any questions or concerns about the diagnosis or treatment options?
